docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone with a history of bee sting allergies shouldn't put too much faith in a skin test that shows the danger has gone away, researchers have found. Writing in a recent issue of The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, scientists from Johns Hopkins said the skin tests used by allergists to detect bee sting allergies were only 90 percent reliable. In the rest of the cases, people who have been given clean bills of health may actually be vulnerable to life-threatening reactions if stung.

headline.main: A Note of Caution on Bee Sting Allergies

docs.abstract: Johns Hopkins researchers report skin tests used by allergists to detect bee sting allergies are only 90 percent reliable; cite need for better testing methods for potentially life-threatening reaction; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Anyone with a history of bee sting allergies shouldn't put too much faith in a skin test that shows the danger has gone away, researchers have found.    Writing in a recent issue of The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, scientists from...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors hoping to reduce the exposure of smokers' children to secondhand smoke have found that putting nicotine monitors in the home seems to help persuade parents to smoke less around their children. Decreasing the levels of smoke is important because young children who live with a smoker have been found to be more susceptible to ear infections, asthma, bronchitis and pneumonia than those who do not.

headline.main: Clearing the Air for Children of Smokers

docs.abstract: Dana-Farber Cancer Institute researchers find putting nicotine monitors in home seems to help persuade parents to smoke less around their children; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors hoping to reduce the exposure of smokers' children to secondhand smoke have found that putting nicotine monitors in the home seems to help persuade parents to smoke less around their children.    Decreasing the levels of smoke is important...

docs.lead_paragraph: Differences in the care given to black and white asthma patients may help explain why blacks suffer more severe symptoms and generally fare worse with the disease, researchers reported yesterday. Writing in The Archives of Internal Medicine, researchers from Johns Hopkins said the care given to blacks failed to meet national guidelines for asthma treatment more often than that given to whites.

headline.main: Racial Gap Found in Asthma Treatments

docs.abstract: Johns Hopkins researchers report differences in care given to black and white asthma patients may help explain why blacks suffer more severe symptoms and generally fare worse with disease; find care given blacks failed to meet national treatment guidelines more often than care given whites (M)
docs.snippet: Differences in the care given to black and white asthma patients may help explain why blacks suffer more severe symptoms and generally fare worse with the disease, researchers reported yesterday.    Writing in The Archives of Internal Medicine,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite many attempts to ease parents' fears about fever, many are still overly concerned about it, often to the potential detriment of their children. In a recent report, researchers at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center in Baltimore noted that ''fever phobia persists'' among parents of young children, and that health care workers might not be doing enough to calm parents. In fact, doctors and nurses often seem to add to parents' concern, resulting in unnecessary calls and visits to the doctor.

headline.main: Easing Parents' Anxiety Over a Child's Fever

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on need to calm parents' fears about fever in young children; notes fever is not illness but symptom of body's efforts to counter disturbance; notes it helps body combat viruses and bacteria; warns drugs to bring down fever, while making child more comfortable, may delay recovery (M)
docs.snippet: Despite many attempts to ease parents' fears about fever, many are still overly concerned about it, often to the potential detriment of their children.    In a recent report, researchers at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center in Baltimore noted that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Terry Coffey was 27 weeks pregnant when she was admitted to the hospital for observation because her blood pressure had shot up and her obstetrician worried that her life might be in danger. The diagnosis was preeclampsia, a disorder that is characterized mainly by the sudden onset of high blood pressure during pregnancy. Mrs. Coffey, a nurse who lives in Westchester County, thought her doctor was overreacting. Although she knew that preeclampsia could be dangerous, she felt fine.

headline.main: Dangerous Complication of Pregnancy Becomes More Common

docs.abstract: Preeclampsia, dangerous pregnancy disorder characterized mainly by sudden onset of high blood pressure, seems to be on rise, with case reports rising by 40 percent in United States over past decade; some experts see rise linked to increasing number of women delaying pregnancy until late 30's and early 40's and to increased use of assisted-reproduction techniques that often result in multiple births; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People who buy valerian, an increasingly popular herbal supplement used as a sleep aid, may not be getting what they are paying for. In a report released yesterday, ConsumerLab, a commercial testing company that regularly examines supplements produced by a booming herbal-remedy industry, said that many valerian products had serious quality-control problems.

headline.main: Quality of Herbal Sleep Aid Is Criticized

docs.abstract: ConsumerLab reports many products containing valerian, increasingly popular herbal supplement used as sleep aid, have serious quality control problems; finds only 9 of 17 products tested past muster; cites concern that some companies might have unintentionally used wrong species of valerian, some of which might be toxic; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: People who buy valerian, an increasingly popular herbal supplement used as a sleep aid, may not be getting what they are paying for.    In a report released yesterday, ConsumerLab, a commercial testing company that regularly examines supplements...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors testing patients for prostate cancer can significantly increase the number of cases they spot by taking more tissue samples, a recent study found. Writing in the journal Urologic Oncology, researchers from Ohio State University said the current method might miss the disease in one out of seven cases.

headline.main: More Samples Urged in Prostate Testing

docs.abstract: Ohio State University researchers find doctors testing patients for prostate cancer can significantly increase number of cases they spot by taking more tissue samples; find current method might miss disease in one out of seven cases (S)
docs.snippet: Doctors testing patients for prostate cancer can significantly increase the number of cases they spot by taking more tissue samples, a recent study found.    Writing in the journal Urologic Oncology, researchers from Ohio State University said the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Who owns your body? Why, you do, of course. Like your first vote and first legal drink, your first time alone in the doctor's office was a rite of passage, the moment you were finally acknowledged sovereign of your own flesh and bone, chief operating officer of your bowels and sole spokesman for your pores, while your former regent, now deposed, leafed through magazines in the waiting room. Or so the theory goes. The reality is that few adults retain dominion over their own health care for long. Other people keep infiltrating the territory. They show up in phone calls, in notes, in hissed asides to the doctor while the patient changes. Sometimes they just toss the magazine aside and head into the examining room to take over, a coup d'état of body custody in the name of a higher good.

headline.main: When Third Parties Dispense Second Opinions

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger Cases column on delicate matter of treating patients when some of information about their health comes from third parties, such as a spouse, mother or social worker; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study to be reported on Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine is fueling a running disagreement among medical researchers over the unresolved issues in Lyme disease, a tick-borne illness that is endemic in much of the Northeast and in other pockets around the nation. The study, by Dr. Mark S. Klempner of Boston University Medical Center, showed that prolonged treatment with antibiotics was no more effective than placebos among those with persistent Lyme disease symptoms.

headline.main: Certainty and Uncertainty in Treatment of Lyme Disease

docs.abstract: Study by Dr Mark S Klempner, to be published in New England Journal of Medicine, which found prolonged treatment with antibiotics is no more effective than placebos among those with persistent Lyme disease symptoms, fuels running disagreement among medical researchers; journal, citing study's importance to patients and doctors, posted study on Internet month ago; at issue is why symptoms persist or recur in a few patients treated successfully with antibiotics for disease; researchers who suspect Lyme bacteria triggers autoimmune disorder before being wiped out by antibiotics see study as confirmation of their views; other researchers believe bacteria may hide out in body and call for testing of much heavier antibiotic doses; questions and answers about Lyme disease; map; photos (M)
